title: Niagara police declare ‘bagpipe amnesty’ to help youth pipers’ band | Globalnews.ca

organizations.name: the canadian press  niagara regional police

text:
February 1, 2017 2:09 pm Niagara police declare ‘bagpipe amnesty’ to help youth pipers’ band By Staff The Canadian Press 
Niagara Regional Police are asking for the public's help in acquiring unused bagpipes to help the NRPS Pipe Band. Francis Vachon / File / The Canadian Press What is this? 
Sponsored content is written by Global News' editorial staff without any editorial influence by the sponsor. If you'd like to learn more... X What is this? 
Sponsored content is written by Global News' without any editorial influence by the sponsor. If you'd like to learn more... - Listen 
NIAGARA FALLS, Ont. – A southern Ontario police force has declared a “bagpipe amnesty.” 
Niagara regional police are calling on anyone with “an old set of bagpipes lying under a bed or tucked away in the attic” to turn them in. 
The force says the NRPS Pipe Band is running out of bagpipes and is hoping the public can help. Media Release: Other – BAGPIPE AMNESTY – https://t.co/YjQWnymxfl 
— NRPS (@NiagRegPolice) February 1, 2017 
It says its ongoing youth teaching program – called “The Big NOISE”– has a roster of young pipers in need of instruments. 
Police say it’s time to get the unused bagpipes back in action and the amnesty will give new life to old pipes. 
Anyone with unused pipes is urged to call Niagara region police to “discuss in detail the good things” that can be done with them. © 2017 The Canadian Press
